results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [April 2010]
results.creator_credit: Reginald Relf, Ralph Basson, John Vincent, Jack Holdsworth, Hugh Melville, Grant Coultman-Smith, Gordon White, Con Bell, Bob Gatherum, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Nine Victorian war veterans tell of their service during various wars for Australia. Covering World War II and the Vietnam War, these men share their experiences, joys and traumas of this time that would shape the rest of their lives. Created as part of ‘In our words : stories from Victorian veterans’ Digital Storytelling project at ACMI.
results.title_for_label: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [April 2010]
results.creator_credit_for_label: Reginald Relf, Ralph Basson, John Vincent, Jack Holdsworth, Hugh Melville, Grant Coultman-Smith, Gordon White, Con Bell, Bob Gatherum, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Nine Victorian war veterans tell of their service during various wars for Australia. Covering World War II and the Vietnam War, these men share their experiences, joys and traumas of this time that would shape the rest of their lives. Created as part of ‘In our words : stories from Victorian veterans’ Digital Storytelling project at ACMI.
description_for_label: Nine Victorian war veterans tell of their service during various wars for Australia. Covering World War II and the Vietnam War, these men share their experiences, joys and traumas of this time that would shape the rest of their lives. Created as part of ‘In our words : stories from Victorian veterans’ Digital Storytelling project at ACMI.

results.title: In our water
results.brief_description: South Brunswick, New Jersey; Spring, 1975. Frank Kaler and his family are convinced there is something wrong with their water; vegetables cooked in it change colour, skin lesions appear after bathing in it. The health department claims that it is drinkable, but it is later determined to be some of the most toxic drinking water in the country.
results.description: South Brunswick, New Jersey; Spring, 1975. The health department claims that it is drinkable, but it is later determined to be some of the most toxic drinking water in the country.

results.title: In our own backyards: uranium mining in the United States
results.creator_credit: Pamela Jones, Sussanna Styron and Eleventh Hour Films
results.brief_description: The mining and milling of uranium involves the stripping of vast areas of land, reduction of local water tables, release of radioactive gases into the air, and the creation of millions of tons of radioactive waste. This film explores the impact of this process on the environment, the health of the workers and nearby residents. Also explores social justice issues relating to exploitation of Navajo Indian workforce by the mining companies - to the detriment of the health of the native Americans so employed. Environmental health issues (affecting Navajo Indians living in the mines’ vicinity) are a further focus.
results.title_for_label: In our own backyards: uranium mining in the United States
results.creator_credit_for_label: Pamela Jones, Sussanna Styron and Eleventh Hour Films

results.title: In other words
results.creator_credit: Jan Padgett, George Johnson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In other words examines the effects of homophobia on gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender teens. Using interviews, animation, music, classroom discussion and dictionary definitions, this documentary aims to demystify homophobic language and to alert the viewer to its harmful effects. Although the documentary covers sophisticated territory, for example the difference between sexuality and gender identity, regular reference to the personal experiences of teenagers gives it clarity and relevancy. “In other words” is suitable for an audience aged 12-18.

results.title: In other lands: Bohemia
results.creator_credit: Clyde E. Elliott and Post Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: The formation of the Czechoslovak Republic at the close of the World War brought together as the Czech, or Bohemian, nation the Slavs of Bohemia, Moravia and Slovakia. Czechoslovakia owes its sound financial and industrial position to men who ome of that enduring Slavic stock which for centuries has dominated Bohemia and Moravia. Shows Bohemians in traditional peasant dress and tells of the Bohemian farming peasants way of life - selling their produce at the market, attending church, celebrating a wedding, and particularly focuses on their various costume of dress. Photography by Horace C. Shimeld.
